0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-chicago-budget-idUSKBN13B2E6	Chicago City Council passes mayor's 2017 budget	"
By Karen Pierog and Renita D. Young
| CHICAGO

CHICAGO The Chicago City Council on Wednesday approved Mayor Rahm Emanuel's fiscal 2017 budget which calls for a tax on plastic bags and the first phase of hiring more than 900 police officers.The council voted 48-0 for the budget which begins on Jan. 1.Emanuel last month unveiled his $9.8 billion all-funds spending plan
column2: which includes $3.7 billion for operations. The budget relies on $82.3 million in revenue growth
column3: savings from efficiencies
column4: and a few one-time measures - but no big tax hike.""To think that we're on the verge today of passing a budget with almost unanimity is remarkable
column5: Alderman Ed Burke said just before the vote.

column1: Emanuel last year pushed through a $543 million phased-in property tax increase for police and firefighter retirement systems. The city enacted a new tax on water and sewer usage in September to rescue its largest pension fund for municipal workers from insolvency. The council previously increased a telephone surcharge for laborers' pensions.Credit ratings for the nation's third-largest city have been deteriorating due largely to an unfunded pension liability that stood at $33.8 billion at the end of fiscal 2015 for Chicago's four retirement systems. The new budget includes a 7-cent fee on store bags and parking rate hikes. It also accommodates the initial phase of the mayor's two-year plan to add 970 police positions to address the city's sharp spike in violence.
This is the first year in recent memory that we've made investments in public safety with the addition of 1
column2: 000 police officers
column3: said Alderman Jason Earvin. ""And we can direct investment in some of the most challenged communities ... and with our youth in some of the most troubled parts of the city.""After the vote
column4: Emanuel noted record-high summer job creation for youth
column5: record-high project starts in commercial and residential real estate and the city using reforms to place pensions on the path to solvency.

column1: Chicago's employment is at a 15-year high that we haven't seen since 2000 since the tech bubble
column2: Emanuel said. ""What we have done
column3: not just today
column4: but over the last five years is give people confidence in the city that we are going to take care of our business
column5: get our fiscal house in order."" (Editing by Matthew Lewis)"	[]	['creation']

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-obama-democracy-idUSKBN13B1TR	In valedictory speech

column1: By Jeff Mason
| ATHENS

ATHENS President Barack Obama extolled the strengths of democracy from its Greek birthplace on Wednesday in a valedictory speech aimed at highlighting the values he sought to respect in office and prodding his Republican successor
column2: Donald Trump
column3: to follow suit.On a farewell trip to Europe
column4: Obama tried to reassure allies that core U.S. priorities
column5: including a commitment to the NATO military alliance
column6: would continue under Trump
column7: despite the New York businessman's campaign trail statements that called that commitment into question.Obama portrayed the United States as an example of democracies prizing the peaceful transfer of power
column8: even when ideas between the incoming and outgoing leaders are opposed.""The next American president and I could not be more different
column9: he said to an audience in Athens. ""We have very different points of view
column10: but American democracy is bigger than any one person."" Obama took care of some local business in his speech. He urged creditors to help Greece dig out of its mountain of debt and called on young people to stay in the country to spur its economic recovery.But his broader message extended beyond Athens. Step-by-step
column11: Obama listed the values of U.S. democracy that he and fellow Democrats in the United States have accused Trump of violating during his presidential campaign
column12: an implicit call on his successor to change course.

column1: In the same way that democracies are based on the peaceful resolution of disagreements within society
column2: so cooperation is  the best way to resolve conflicts with nations
column3: he said.""That's how with diplomacy we were able to shut down Iran's nuclear weapons program without firing a shot (and) with diplomacy the United States opened relations with Cuba
column4: Obama said
column5: referring to two important milestones of his presidency.He noted how U.S. democracy had evolved to provide rights to women
column6: African Americans
column8: and the gay community.Trump has been criticized for his attitudes toward women and for making fun of a disabled reporter. He has pledged to ban Muslims temporarily from entering the United States and to deport undocumented immigrants who are living in the country illegally.

column1: Democracy is why the United States welcomes ""people of all races
column2: and all religions and all backgrounds and immigrants who strive to give their children a better life
column3: Obama said.""Our democracies show that we are stronger than terrorists
column4: fundamentalists and absolutists
column5: who can't tolerate difference. ""Democracy is stronger than organizations like ISIS
column6: he said
column7: using one of the names for Islamic State.

column1: Because our democracies are inclusive
column2: we are able to welcome people
column3: and refugees in need
column4: to our countries. And nowhere have we seen that compassion more evident than here in Greece
column5: he said
column6: referring to the Greek response to Europe's migrant crisis.Obama highlighted the importance of a free press to expose injustice. Trump banned certain news outlets from his campaign events for writing stories he did not like. The Obama administration has been criticized for its record on press freedom as well
column7: particularly for prosecuting government sources who leak information to journalists. In his speech
column8: Obama highlighted the importance of an independent judiciary to uphold the rule of law. During his campaign
column9: Trump accused a U.S. judge of not being able to be impartial because of his Mexican heritage.Obama also noted that elections hold leaders accountable.""Any action by a president or any result of an election or any legislation that is proven flawed can be corrected through the process of democracy
column10: he said. (Additional reporting by Renee Maltezou and Karolina Tagaris and Michele Kambas in Athens Editing by Jeremy Gaunt)"	['Trump'

column2: even if successful
column3: would add only modestly to world demand. China dominates the global copper market
column4: accounting for half of all demand
column5: and an uptick in consumption there following further stimulus is much more relevant to the market.That
column6: together with less mine supply than expected
column8: but not the wild frenzy that erupted after the U.S. election last week
column9: investors and analysts said.""The infrastructure ambitions of Trump I think are meaningless in terms of the course and direction of commodities

column11: founder and chief investment officer of Eclectica Asset Management
column12: which has around $200 million under management. Copper prices soared about 25 percent from the start of the month to a peak of $6
column15: 466 by Wednesday - still nearly a fifth higher since the start of 2016.Experts brush off the impact on copper of plans by the incoming U.S. president to spend $1 trillion over 10 years on building infrastructure

column2: considering that existing infrastructure would be replaced rather than expanded.""A position paper by Trump's advisors about his infrastructure plans (bit.ly/2eBQB1Y) published before the election did not mention specific projects

7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-china-report-security-idUSKBN13B1W3	U.S. panel urges probe on whether China weakening U.S. militarily	"
By David Brunnstrom
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON A U.S. advisory commission warned on Wednesday that China's growing military might may make it more likely to use force to pursue its interests and called for a government probe into how far outsourcing to China has weakened the U.S. defense industry.The annual report of the U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission pointed to a growing threat to U.S. national security from Chinese spying
column2: including infiltration of U.S. organizations
column3: and called on Congress to bar Chinese state enterprises from acquiring control of U.S. firms.The release of the report to Congress comes a week after Donald Trump won the U.S. presidential election. Trump
column4: an outspoken Republican who has vowed to take a tougher line in trade and security dealings with China than President Barack Obama
column5: will take office on Jan. 20.The panel is a bipartisan body set up in 2000 to monitor the national security implications of the U.S. trade and economic relationship with China and to make recommendations to Congress for legislative and administrative action.Its report also called on Congress to back more frequent U.S. Navy freedom-of-navigation operations in the South China Sea
column6: one of the world's busiest trade routes where China's building of artificial islands with military facilities has raised concerns about future freedom of movement. Beijing and its neighbors have conflicting territorial claims there.

column1: The commission said ongoing reforms of the People's Liberation Army would strengthen Beijing's hand and noted that China was close to completing its first domestically produced aircraft carrier.""China's pursuit of expeditionary capabilities
column2: coupled with the aggressive trends that have been displayed in both the East and South China Seas
column3: are compounding existing concerns about China's rise among U.S. allies and partners in the greater Asia
column4: the report said.

column1: Given its enhanced strategic lift capability
column2: strengthened employment of special operations forces
column3: increasing capabilities of surface vessels and aircraft
column4: and more frequent and sophisticated experience operating abroad
column5: China may also be more inclined to use force to protect its interests
column6: it said.The panel said that U.S. responses to the threat from Chinese intelligence gathering had suffered from a lack of a coordinated effort by U.S. intelligence agencies.It said Congress should also direct the U.S. Government Accountability Office to prepare a report ""examining the extent to which large-scale outsourcing of manufacturing activities to China is leading to the hollowing out of the U.S. defense industrial base.""

column1: This report should also detail the national security implications of a diminished domestic industrial base (including assessing any impact on U.S. military readiness)
column2: compromised U.S. military supply chains
column3: and reduced capability to manufacture state-of-the-art military systems and equipment
column4: it said.The commission's report also recommended that Congress call on the U.S. State Department to produce educational materials to alert U.S. citizens overseas and students going to China to the dangers of recruitment efforts by Chinese agents. (Reporting by David Brunnstrom; Editing by Cynthia Osterman)"	['Trump']	[]

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-sec-analysis-idUSKBN13B0E2	A post-Trump SEC could shake up current policy	"
By Sarah N. Lynch
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON It will be a new day at the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission after President-elect Donald Trump installs his choice to run the agency.With Trump's transition team already in regulatory-relief mode and promising to revamp the Dodd-Frank financial reform legislation
column2: some rules already are marked for death or dialback.Expected on the chopping block soon after Trump takes the oath of office is a proposal that would require companies to disclose pay ratios between their CEOs and employees. Another would require companies to disclose whether their products contain conflict minerals -- minerals that were mined in a war-torn region of Africa.Dead for now is any prospect of the SEC approving a tough fiduciary rule for financial advisers
column3: say policy experts.Trump's decision to tap former Republican SEC Commissioner Paul Atkins to help manage the Trump team's transition efforts at the SEC and other financial agencies offers a window into some other changes that could be in store. Atkins
column4: the founder of the regulatory consulting firm Patomak Global Partners
column5: is viewed by some to be a top contender for the position of SEC chairman itself
column6: though as the transition head he could also recommend someone else for that job.  Atkins' well-known conservative views on everything from enforcement penalties to corporate governance are likely to be reflected in the SEC's agenda.Here are five policy areas likely to change.CORPORATE AUDITING RULES COULD GET LOOSER

column1: Paul Atkins was a staunch critic of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB)
column2: a body created after the Enron accounting scandal to police and write new rules for corporate auditors.Atkins raised concerns about the board's budget and high salaries
column3: and advocated against prescriptive accounting rules that he felt constrained auditors from making professional judgments.Recently
column4: Republicans have criticized the PCAOB for taking on more progressive causes
column5: such as proposing companies rotate auditors to reduce conflicts or requiring accounting firms to disclose the name of individual partners working on company audits.The PCAOB's chairman Jim Doty
column6: who advocated for the controversial reform measures
column7: will almost certainly not be re-appointed by the incoming SEC chair.

column1: I expect that a new Chair will refocus the Board's standard-setting agenda on the core audit function
column2: said Hunton & Williams Partner Scott Kimpel. ""I would expect a return to the basics.""PENALTIES COULD SHRINK; PEOPLE COULD PAY

column1: The topic of whether to impose corporate penalties against a company would come under scrutiny.During his time at the SEC
column2: Atkins advocated for an enforcement approach that he said did not unduly punish corporate shareholders that had already suffered from the misconduct. He called for the SEC to carefully weigh who had profited from the bad behavior
column3: and urged the SEC to hold individuals accountable for their actions.

column1: STOCK MARKET TRADING WOULD GET SECOND LOOK

Atkins has long opined that the SEC's rules requiring ""best price"" execution of stock trades actually skews the market by causing fragmentation and harming price discovery by directing orders away from traditional stock exchanges into ""dark pool"" trading platforms.As a commissioner
column2: Paul Atkins was critical of the rule called Regulation National Market System (NMS)
column3: saying it could impede true price discovery and encourage gaming of the system.In January 2016 he wrote an opinion piece in the Wall Street Journal calling for the SEC to do major surgery on the rule
column4: allowing considerations beyond 'best price' and speed to determine order flow.WHISTLEBLOWERS COULD FACE MORE HURDLES

column1: The Dodd-Frank law gave the SEC newfound powers to reward whistleblowers who come forward with tips of corporate malfeasance.
From August 2011 through fiscal year 2015
column2: the SEC has received more than 14
column3: 000 tips
column4: and by August of 2016
column5: the program had given out more than $100 million in rewards.But corporate America has long disliked the part of the rule that protects whistleblowers from having to report wrongdoing to their own companies before they tip off the government.In 2011
column6: Atkins urged the SEC to require whistleblowers to report internally first
column7: saying a failure to do so could undermine compliance programs.Whether this will change remains to be seen
column8: especially in the wake of the Wells Fargo & Co scandal
column9: where employees who reported internally about the opening of unauthorized accounts were fired.Atkins ""cares deeply about the commission and its enforcement program
column11: a whistleblower attorney at Labaton Sucharow who previously worked in the SEC's enforcement division during Atkins' tenure.""I find it very hard to believe that he would support undermining such a successful program.""CAPITAL FORMATION COULD GET A BOOST

column1: Atkins was a strong proponent of the 2012 Jump Start Our Business Startups Act
column2: which scaled back some SEC rules to help smaller companies raise capital.In testimony on Capitol Hill
column3: Atkins advocated for additional steps to be taken to help smaller companies
column4: including rules to help create venture exchanges for mid-cap stocks and broadening efforts to exempt private capital-raising rules from regulation by states. (Reporting by Sarah N. Lynch; editing by Linda Stern and Diane Craft)"	['Paul'
column5: 'Jordan'
column6: 'Lynch'
